Mideast Peace Talks To Continue Without Clinton President Clinton announced that the Israeli Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, decided to remain at Camp David while he flew off to Japan to continue searching for a solution for peace with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.

President Between Summits President Clinton has yet to be briefed on his role at a meeting in Okinawa of leaders of the world's seven leading industrial nations and Russia. The meeting begins on Friday.

Proposal on Digital Divide A task force established by the World Economic Forum urged the leading industrial nations and Russia to take action to erase a growing digital divide resulting from the economic chasm separating the developed and developing worlds.

North Korean Missile Offer President Vladmir V. Putin of Russia said North Korea had offered to abandon its missile program if other nations would provide it with rockets to launch satellites into space. Mr. Putin announced the offer following a meeting with the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il.

Path Clear for Putin's Plan Russia's lower house of Parliament cleared the way for President Putin to strengthen central control over the country's far-flung regions by giving him the right to disband local legislatures and fire regional governors who break the law.

Another Leak From Blair Camp For the second time this week, a damaging memorandum from the inner circle of Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain has been leaked to major newspapers and has caused embarrassment to his government as it struggles to keep its once-high popular appeal from continuing its present swoon.

Guerrilla Attacks in Colombia Colombia's largest guerrilla group has carried out attacks on towns and police headquarters, killing more than 200 people, in an apparent response to the passage in the United States Congress of $1.3 billion in aid for Colombia's armed forces.

U.S. Delays Dam Breaching Intended to Aid Salmon The Clinton administration will postpone by at least five years a plan that could have led to the breaching of four major Snake River dams for the benefit of wild salmon in the Pacific Northwest. Officials will propose smaller steps to protect the fish.

Loyalty as Bush's Top Criterion Gov. George W. Bush and his presidential campaign advisers have made clear that one of the litmus tests of a running mate will be a steadfast faithfulness to the governor. Senator John McCain of Arizona, a political maverick, is seen as an improbable selection.
President Clinton has told friends and associates that two of his favorite choices for Vice President Al Gore's running mate are former Senator George J. Mitchell and Senator Bob Graham.
Vice President Gore said he would travel to Governor Bush's backyard in Texas to highlight the state's budget woes.

F.B.I. Agents Seize Manuscript F.B.I. agents seized a computer hard drive from the home of a former Energy Department intelligence official, Notra Trulock, in an effort to determine whether his unpublished manuscript disclosed classified information, U.S. officials said.
Boosting Retirement Savings The House passed a proposal to strengthen retirement savings plans by permitting workers to make larger contributions to them.

Shift on Colon Cancer Tests The test most commonly recommended to screen healthy adults for colorectal cancer misses too many precancerous growths and should be replaced by a more extensive procedure that examines the entire colon, doctors reported.

Suit Over Contraceptives Planned Parenthood filed a class-action lawsuit charging that a company whose health insurance plan covers most prescription drugs, but excludes contraceptives, is illegally discriminating against its female employees.

Lazio Gets Donations From Industry He Aided Representative Rick A. Lazio has championed legislation for the manufactured housing industry even as he has pursued the industry's donations, collecting more than $95,000 since 1995. Mr. Lazio has excelled at harvesting money from donors with legislation before him, particularly those involved in housing issues, according to an examination of his campaign records.

Giuliani to Curtail Tax Cuts Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, acknowledging that the city's projected deficits were ''too large,'' announced that he would severely curtail tax cuts he had planned for this year, impose a partial hiring freeze and reduce some agency spending.

Museum and School Initiative Edison Schools, the country's largest school management company, and the Museum for African Art are negotiating with New York City officials to build a combined corporate headquarters, school and museum by Central Park.

Clinton Team on the Defensive Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign staff and her surrogates have worked behind the scenes and in public to snuff out the controversy over an accusation that she made an anti-Semitic remark long ago, a charge that she has denied.
Roman Colosseum Comes Alive The Colosseum, the infamous arena of combat and slaughter, is back in business for the first time in 1,500 years, as ''Oedipus Rex'' opens.
William F. Whyte A sociologist with a passion for reform who wrote ''Street Corner Society,'' the trailblazing 1943 study of Italian-American gangs in the North End of Boston, he was 86.

Musicians Find Payoffs Online Tens of thousands of aspiring rock stars are using the Internet to give their music away, and more than a few are beginning to see some payoff. Some receive revenue from MP3.com and other Web sites; most say the main benefit of distributing their songs is attracting an audience that may buy CD's or T-shirts or attend a live performance.
CNet to Buy Ziff-Davis CNet Networks said it would acquire Ziff-Davis, a trailblazer in the technology magazine industry, and its Internet subsidiary, ZDNet, for $1.6 billion in stock.

Confidence in Bank One Investors bought shares of Bank One after its new chief executive announced a $1.91 billion restructuring charge that wiped out the company's second-quarter profit and left it with a loss of $1.27 billion.

Competition for N.T.T. The United States and Japan have reached a trade agreement that will likely make telecommunications services in Japan far more affordable, competitive and diverse. The agreement cuts the fees that Nippon Telegraph and Telephone charges other telecommunications companies to use its domestic network.
